First, part (a): What's the probability that the first progeny is identical to the parent's genotype? Well, when you self-fertilize, each gene independently gets passed on. Since it's heterozygous, each parent contributes one allele, so the chance of getting any specific allele from either parent is 1/2. 

But wait, since there are multiple gene pairs, how do these probabilities multiply? For each gene pair, the probability of getting the correct allele is 1/2. Since the genes are independent, we can multiply the probabilities. So for all five gene pairs, it would be (1/2)^5. Calculating that gives 1/32. So the probability is 1/32. Looking at the options, option E says 1/32 for part (a), but let me check other parts too before deciding.

Part (b): Proportion of the total progeny that's homozygous. Homozygous means both alleles are the same, like AA or aa. For each gene pair, the probability of homozygosity is 1/4 because there are two possibilities: AA or aa, each with 1/2 * 1/2 = 1/4 chance. Since there are five independent genes, the total number of possible genotypes is 2^5 = 32. The number of homozygous genotypes would be 2 (for each gene, AA and aa). So the proportion is 2/32 = 1/16. Checking the options, option E also has 1/16 for part (b).

Since each gene is independently dominant, the probability that a particular individual has all five dominant traits is (1/2)^5 = 1/32. However, wait—no, that's only if both alleles are dominant. Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

<|im_start|>user
Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

(b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

<|im_start|>user
Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>

Problem: Assume there is an organism in which there are five contrasting independent gene pairs, A vs. a, B vs. b, D vs. d, E vs. e and F vs. f, for which the organism is heterozygous. If the organism were able to undergo self-fertilization, (a) what is the probability that the first progeny will have a genotype identical to that of the parent? (b) what proportion of the total progeny will be homozygous? (c) assuming complete dominance for each gene pair, what proportion of the total progeny will phenotypically exhibit the dominant form for the five characters?

A. 1/1024, 1/1024, 1023/1,024

B. 1/16, 3/16, 729/1,024

C. 1/4, 1/4, 512/1,024

D. 1/8, 1/8, 121/1,024

E. 1/32, 1/32, 243/1,024

F. 1/16, 1/16, 81/1,024

G. 1/64, 1/4, 342/1,024

H. 1/2, 1/2, 1/1,024

I. 1/32, 1/64, 255/1,024

J. 1/4, 1/8, 961/1,024
